title: Case Study: Addison's Disease with Associated Musculoskeletal Complaints
clinical_history: A 35-year-old female, Sarah, presents with a history of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle weakness over the past year. She was diagnosed with Addison's disease 6 months ago and has been on corticosteroid replacement therapy since then. Despite treatment, she continues to experience muscle pain and weakness, particularly in the lower extremities. She reports difficulty getting up from a seated position and has noticed increased fatigue after minimal exertion.

nprs.affected_area: Bilateral lower extremity muscle pain, particularly in the quadriceps and hamstrings
Lower back pain, described as a dull ache

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or climbing stairs; lifting heavy objects
picture: A 24-hour picture showing a person with a slightly stooped posture, using a cane for support while walking
easing_factors: Rest, particularly lying down; heat application to the affected areas
past_history: No previous history of musculoskeletal complaints; however, she has a history of autoimmune disorders (Type 1 diabetes)
medical_history: Addison's disease diagnosed 6 months ago; currently on hydrocortisone 20mg/day and fludrocortisone 0.1mg/day
medications: Hydrocortisone 20mg/day, fludrocortisone 0.1mg/day, and occasional acetaminophen for pain
personal_history: Married with two children; works part-time as an administrative assistant; enjoys hiking and reading in her free time
imaging: X-rays of the lumbar spine and pelvis show mild osteopenia; no fractures or other abnormalities noted
